resources.string: Unfamiliar with the virus name which is infecting your tomato plant? Want to detect the virus at an earlier stage or learn about viruses and nutrient deficiencies in tomato plants? virusSafe Agro helps you to detect the virus along with control strategies which helps you to treat the plants thus minimising the chances of losses and damages.

• Instantly detect a virus by which the plant is infected
• Learn more about viruses and nutrient deficiencies in tomato plants
• Get suggestions for treating infected plants using the chemical and non-chemical control strategies
• Tips to grow tomato plants in Victoria
• Know about the happenings in the agriculture industry
• Locate pesticide stores in your vicinity
• Easy-to-use interface with an info guide on what each screen offers
This app will contact a feature to detect virus on tomato fruits and a way to tackle it. Also, revisions will be made based on users feedback.
The app will contain a feature to check nutrient deficiency in tomato plants and way to tackle it, and revisions based on user feedback.
We are open to feedback about this application.

virusSafe Agro does not guarantee the completeness or accuracy of information on this page. virusSafe Agro shall bear no liability or responsibility for any errors, defects, faults or omissions in the information.
This app aims to provide an easy reference to diagnose virus in tomato plants and a care guide for farmers in Victoria who are new to farming.
Click this calculator to get your estimated spending on water per year.
Tap on the tile to know about the chemical sprays that can be used to control the virus spread.
Tap on the tile to know about the organic ways to control the virus spread.
Tap on the tile to read about the causes that gives rise to the spread of virus.
Tap on the tile to know about the environmental conditions that fuel up the virus spread.
Tap on the tile to know read about the happenings in the agricultural industry.
Tap on the tile to know read about the tweets posted by people on twitter.
Tap on the tile to watch videos related to agriculture.
There are 9 types of viruses in tomato plants. Tap on the tile to learn more about them.
There are 11 types of nutrient deficiencies in tomato plants. Tap on the tile to read about the nutrient deficiencies in tomato plants.
Know about the favorable conditions, fertilizers and much more about growing the tomato plants. Tap on the tile to read about the tips to grow tomato plants.
There are nine types of viruses in tomato plants, which causes major damages to the yield. Tap on the tiles below to learn more about the viruses.
Something wrong with the server! Please try again!
Dear user, the location service should be open if you want to try our map for showing your nearest pesticide stores location.
Early blight (EB) usually occurs during early to mid tomato growing season
Mites are favoured by hot dry weather
All other viruses can occur any time during the growing season
There are no such environmental conditions that give rise to SLS, TYLC, LB, and Ff viruses in tomato plants.
• High temperature\n• Day length: The day length (number of hours the plant is exposed to the sun) informs the plants about the seasons\n• Stage of infection: Plant age at the time of infection

• High temperatures
• High humidity
• Overhead irrigation
• Frequent rainfall

• Occurs in any type of weather
• Favours damp conditions
• Strikes after heavy rainfall
• Moderate to warm temperatures
• Mites are favoured by hot dry weather

• Seedlings should be planted when the chances of frost vanishes
• The soil temperature during planting should be 18–20 degrees
• Plant from August
• There should be enough protection from strong winds
• The soil should be prepared with the help of organic matter before planting
• If the plant requires staking, it should be planted 1 metre apart
• Traditional way of planting is between AFL Grand Final and the Melbourne Cup
• Harvest until end of March\n• The best time to harvest the tomatoes is when the tomatoes reaches the breaker stage, i.e., ½ green and ½ pink
• Requires partial-full sun\n• Recommended to have shade during hottest Victorian summer days
• Recommended to use sheep manure as tomatoes are considered to be heavy feeders.
• Seeds can be sown in the start of November to December.

• Should be watered regularly
• The plant may lose fruit in dry period
• Base of the plant should be deeply watered
• Avoid planting the foliage
• Plants should be feed regularly with organic fertilisers\n• Feeding the plants throughout the season results in beautiful yield
• Mulching helps to keep the water in\n• It keeps the weeds out\n• Mulching keeps the roots cool

• Chemical products used: Mancozeb, copper oxychloride, chlorothalonil
• Plants should be treated when the first spots are seen
• Sprayed at 10–14 days interval for three-four weeks
• Should be sprayed on both sides of the leaves
• Chemical products used: Copper fungicides or Copper plus mancozeb\n• Sprayed at 7–10 days interval in the field\n• Spray early when plants are young
• Silverleaf whiteflies can be bought under control using potent chemicals
• Preventive sprays: Copper product, chlorothalonil, mancozeb\n• Systemic products such as strobilurin, dimethomorth, cymoxanil, and metalaxyl should be used

• Chemical products which can be used: Mancozeb, copper oxychloride, chlorothalonil
• Plants should be treated when yellow spots are visible
• The leaves should be sprayed at a 10–14-day intervals
• Use fungicides to give adequate control
• Fungicides include: Mancozeb, Maneb, Chlorothalonil, Copper (Kocide), Penthiopyrad, Boscalid, Pyraclostrobin\n• Sungicides should be applied at the fruit and reapplied every 7–14 days

• Miticide spray should be applied if mites are present on 50% of the leaves\n• Insecticides should be applied only as needed\n• Spraying chemicals to plants should be avoided in hot weathers as they may cause chemical injuries

• Spray copper oxychloride
• Use fungicidal sprays
• Chemicals: Maneb, Chlorothalonil
• Chemicals must be applied at 7–10-day intervals

• Remove plants with symptoms Promptly to prevent the spread of the virus to nearby healthy plants
• On handling infected plants, it’s necessary to wash tools and hands in hot soapy water
• Tools should be sterilised using a disinfectant (Virkon S)
• Avoid growing new plants in close proximity if you suspect your plants are infected

• Remove debris of old plants at the end of growing season
• Avoid planting in the areas where diseased plants where located in the past years
• Plants should be grown in sunlight with proper air circulation
• Avoid crowding of plants

• Grow plants from infection free-seeds
• Purchase high quality seeds
• Use hot water treatment to kill bacteria in seeds
• Remove crop debris at the end of the growing season
• Disinfect pruners and tools by dipping in commercial sanitizer
• Manage flies\n• Remove old crop debris and destroy them

• Rotate crops, avoid planting tomato plants on same land
• Destroy infected plants
• Maintain spacing between plants to ensure air movement
• Remove branches from lower parts of plants
• Burn or dig remains of diseased plants\n• Diseased leaves should be removed\n• Ventilation between leaves can be improved by using pruning practice

• Destroy diseased plants
• Use pathogen free-seed
• Blight remains active for a year, so it is recommended to rotate crops
• Avoid overcrowding of plants so that air can pass through the leaves
• Water the soil instead of plants

• Remove plants with symptoms promptly and destroy infected areas
• Use crop rotation
• Use disease-free seeds
• Overhead watering should be avoided
• Enough room should be provided for air circulation
VirusSafe Agro provides three main features-namely virus detection, learn, and toolkit.

• The virus in tomato leaves can be detected by using this feature.
• The user can either click and upload the image for testing or can upload an image of a tomato leaf from the gallery.
• On uploading the image, the user will get immediate feedback on whether the plant is infected or not.
• The user gets to know the virus name by which the plant is infected.

• Learn provides rich textual content regarding virus types, nutrient deficiencies, and tips to grow tomato plants in Victoria.\n• The user can know about the nine kinds of viruses, eleven nutrient deficiencies along with their description, symptoms, causes, and a photo gallery of infected leaves.\n• They can check their knowledge on readings by attempting a Quiz.

• This feature is a smorgasbord for users to know about the strategies to control viruses, to locate nearby pesticide stores, learn environmental factors leading to virus spread, capability to count tomatoes on the plant as well as an option to differentiate between good and damaged tomato fruits.\n• Lastly, it provides updates about happenings in the farming industry.
• The Learn functionality in virusSafe Agro provides rich textual content related to viruses, nutrient deficiencies, and tips to grow tomato plants in Victoria.

• This functionality provides content related to nine types of viruses in tomato plants.\n• It provides description, symptoms, causes along with the photo gallery of infected leaves.\n• After reading the content, there is a Quiz functionality to check users understanding.
• This functionality provides content related to eleven types of viruses in tomato plants.\n• It provides symptoms, reasons, factors, and correction methods to treat nutrient deficient plants.
• Know about best time to grow, harvest, sow tomato seeds in Victoria, and much more.

• There are nine types of viruses in tomato plants.
• Each tile represents a different virus and provides a description, symptoms, causes, and photo gallery of infected leaves related to each virus.
• After reading the content, there is a Quiz functionality to check the users understanding.
• Users can find virus content quickly by using the search option.

• There are eleven types of nutrient deficiencies in tomato plants.\n• Each tile represents a different nutrient deficiency and provides symptoms , factors, and correction methods to treat nutrient deficient plants.\n• Users can find nutrient deficiency content quickly by using the search option.
• Know about best time to grow, harvest, sow tomato seeds in Victoria, and much more.

• This feature is a smorgasbord for users to know about the strategies to control viruses, to locate nearby pesticide stores, learn environmental factors leading to virus spread, capability to count tomatoes on the plant as well as an option to differentiate between good and damaged tomato fruits.\n• Lastly, it provides updates about happenings in the farming industry.

• Each virus can be controlled using chemical and non-chemical control strategies.\n• Find more about how the viruses can be treated/controlled at an earlier stage so that losses can be minimised.\n• Each virus type has different chemical and non-chemical ways to control the virus.

• Factors provides two options-namely timing of cause and environmental conditions.\n• Timing of cause gives information about seasons in which the virus is most likely to infect the plants.\n• Environmental conditions provide information related to conditions that favour viruses in tomato plants.

• The insights screen provides two options-namely News and Tweets.\n• Using the News functionality, the users can read about the happenings in the agricultural industry.\n• Tweets functionality allows the users to read tweets posted by people about farming.

• The map shows nearby pesticide stores based on user’s location.
• Users can easily navigate to the pesticide store using the directions option.
• The user’s current location is denoted by a Tomato icon.
• If the pesticide shop is closed the Spray icon is highlight by grey color else, is highlighted by purple color.
1. Avoid dark and blurry images by focusing on the leaf, which is suspected to be infected.
2. Make sure the leaves of the tomato plant are clear, avoid getting too close.
It is not a tomato leaf image! Please try again!
